  "log": null,
  "summary": "This is a usage/question, not a bug. The reporter asked whether RE2 interprets \\x escapes in replacement strings; the project maintainer clarified that Perl also does not interpret \\x in regex replacement strings (the example shows the escape is left literal) and that escape interpretation is the responsibility of the host language's ordinary string literals (e.g., C). Therefore the described behavior is expected and the report reflects a misunderstanding rather than a defect in RE2."
}

The provided patch increases the required space to 5 and uses sprintf_s on Windows. This is a real memory bug (potential overflow); it appears to be found by manual inspection and a patch is suggested in the issue text, but no commit/PR or merge is referenced so it is not marked as fixed here."
}

  "log": "strace excerpt:
brk(0xdef200)                           = 0xdef200

access("/etc/ld.so.nohwcap", F_OK)      = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
futex(0xdd02f4, FUTEX_WAIT_PRIVATE, 0, NULL

gdb backtrace excerpts:
#0  pthread_rwlock_wrlock () at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/pthread_rwlock_wrlock.S:85
#1  0x0000000000445bce in Lock (this=0x7da2e8) at ./util/mutex.h:111
#2  MutexLock (mu=0x7da2e8, this=<synthetic pointer>) at ./util/mutex.h:151
#3  RunStateOnByteUnlocked (c=<optimised out>, state=0x7db370, this=0x7da2d0) at re2/dfa.cc:962

#0  pthread_rwlock_wrlock () at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/pthread_rwlock_wrlock.S:34
#1  0x00000000004224c1 in re2::Mutex::Lock (this=0x7e2218) at ./util/mutex.h:113
#2  0x000000000044510b in MutexLock (mu=0x7e2218, this=<synthetic pointer>) at ./util/mutex.h:153
#3  re2::Prog::GetDFA (this=0x7e21f0, kind=re2::Prog::kLongestMatch) at re2/dfa.cc:1815

Mutex logging added by developer:
./util/mutex.h:111: 0xbaed40 pthread_rwlock_init(&mutex_, NULL)
./util/mutex.h:111: 0xbaf198 pthread_rwlock_init(&mutex_, NULL)
./util/mutex.h:113: 0xbaf198 pthread_rwlock_wrlock(&mutex_)
./util/mutex.h:111: 0xbaf348 pthread_rwlock_init(&mutex_, NULL)

./util/mutex.h:113: 0xbaf348 pthread_rwlock_wrlock(&mutex_)

Developer diagnosis notes (from comments): when statically linked pthread_rwlock_wrlock() did not set __writer and pthread_rwlock_unlock() decremented __nr_readers (unsigned) from 0 to 4294967295, causing a writer to wait forever. Workarounds that worked: removing --static, using -Wl,--whole-archive -lpthread -Wl,--no-whole-archive, or changes applied in commit e37a0e81ffedb9c8e7fdd75a17736a30208545a7.",
  "summary": "Running the testinstall binary statically linked on Ubuntu 14.10/15.04 caused the program to hang (and on 15.04 to core dump) due to pthread read-write lock state being incorrect when statically linked. This is a real crash/hang affecting re2 when built with --static; the developers diagnosed the pthread/rwlock interaction and added a fix (commit e37a0e81...) and referenced a Launchpad bug for the system issue. I classify it as a CRASH discovered by manual testing; reproduction is the provided static compile+run commands and the issue was marked as resolved by the cited commit."
}

  "summary": "The report describes slow execution for a specific pattern when using RE2's FullMatch (pattern: \".*?AAA\\s+(\\d+)\\s+(FOO|BAR).*\"), compared to Python's re and to RE2 PartialMatch. RE2 maintainers explained that FullMatch triggers the BitState engine which is much slower for this pattern, whereas PartialMatch uses faster DFA/OnePass paths (and memchr optimizations), and the reporter confirmed PartialMatch is much faster. This is expected behavior/performance tradeoff based on the chosen API and pattern, not a defect in RE2, so it is not classified as a bug." 
}

The reporter suggested a Makefile change (remove -static, add -std=c++11) but no upstream commit/PR was referenced in the issue."

Therefore this is not a defect in re2 but an expected regex behavior/misuse."
}

  "summary": "This issue is a usage/question about how certain single-character and malformed regexes are parsed rather than a report of incorrect behavior. A project member explained that RE2/Go regexp parsing follows Perl-like rules: '[' must start a character class (so lone '[' is an error) while '[[]' is a class containing '['; '{' can fall back to a literal if it doesn't form a repetition; unexpected ']' or '}' are treated as literals, and unexpected ')' is an error. The reporter's observations match these documented parsing behaviors, so there is no bug to fix." 
}

  "summary": "The reporter shows that building and running re2 tests on Solaris 11.3 with Oracle Developer Studio 12.6 causes crashes (SEGV) inside std::initializer_list::begin called from Prog::MarkSuccessors. The stack trace and behavior strongly indicate a compiler miscompilation of a temporary initializer_list; the reporter supplied a local workaround patch that replaces the range-for over an initializer_list with an explicit vector and reports that tests then pass. This qualifies as a real crash issue (CRASH) observed via manual build and testing; it appears to be a compiler bug rather than a semantic bug in re2, and no upstream fix/PR is recorded in the thread."

  "summary": "The report shows Valgrind reporting three "still reachable" allocations from RE2's lazy initialization (empty_string, empty_named_groups, empty_group_names) when creating an RE2 object (example: re2::RE2 x("x")). This is a memory-class issue (allocations that outlive program termination trigger Valgrind reports). The maintainers acknowledged the behaviour, implemented a change to avoid "immortal" dynamic allocations, and marked it fixed in commit 4be2407. Reproduction: constructing an RE2 with pattern "x" (compiled with -DRE2_ON_VALGRIND=1) on Valgrind 3.15 triggers the reported reachable allocations."
}

I classify this as a MEMORY bug found by manual runtime testing with Valgrind, reproducible with pattern ".*llo" on input "Hello"."
}

  "log": "Is it expected that `absl::*::Mutex::(un)lock_shared` operations will dominate runtime when a `re2::RE2` object is shared among threads?\n\nI noticed this issue when analyzing why switch to RE2 causes significant slowdown in https://github.com/falconindy/pkgfile/pull/72. It's so bad, that doing the work in a single thread was faster than splitting it among threads. `perf` shows 80-90% of time is spent in the lock operations (https://github.com/falconindy/pkgfile/pull/72#issuecomment-3240234887).\n\nHere are my results from testing with hyperfine:\n| Command | Mean [ms] | Min [ms] | Max [ms] | Relative |\n|:---|---:|---:|---:|---:|\n| `build/re2-separate` | 173.2 ± 12.2 | 163.8 | 217.5 | 1.63 ± 0.15 |\n| `build/re2-shared` | 966.8 ± 116.4 | 861.5 | 1170.4 | 9.10 ± 1.21 |\n| `build/pcre-shared` | 123.6 ± 18.1 | 104.2 | 170.8 | 1.16 ± 0.18 |\n| `build/pcre-separate` | 106.3 ± 6.0 | 96.1 | 119.2 | 1.00 |",
  "summary": "The reporter provides a small C++ reproducer and perf/hyperfine measurements showing that sharing a single re2::RE2 object across threads causes heavy lock contention (absl::Mutex shared locks), resulting in a large performance regression compared to per-thread RE2 instances and compared to PCRE. This is a real performance bug (PERF) as it demonstrably degrades multi-threaded throughput; no fix or commit is mentioned in the report. The issue was discovered via manual testing and profiling (perf/hyperfine) and the repro pattern/input are provided in the issue."
}
